title: 111_s3026
content: Any concurrent resolution on the budget introduced under subsection (a) must comply with section 301. When a concurrent resolution on the budget is agreed to, the aggregates, allocations, and reconciliation directives in the report or resolution will be considered as such for sections 302, 303, and 311 for the relevant fiscal years. The resolution will be treated as a joint resolution for all purposes of the title and the Rules of the House of Representatives. The table of contents in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended by inserting a new item after section 315, referencing the agreed date for concurrent resolutions. SEC. 275. AMENDMENTS TO JOINT RESOLUTIONS ON THE BUDGET. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 include redefining a joint resolution on the budget and changing instances of "concurrent" to "joint" in various sections. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 involve changing references from "concurrent" to "joint" resolutions and redefining the most recent budget resolution. "Permissible revisions of budget resolutions include changing references from 'concurrent' to 'joint' resolutions and redefining the most recent budget resolution." Sec. 304 allows for the revision or reaffirmation of the joint resolution on the budget for a fiscal year. The chairman of the Budget Committee may adjust levels as needed for budget resolution enforcement. Sections 302, 303, 310, and 311 are amended to replace "agreed to" with "enacted." Additionally, section 3 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to change "concurrent" to "joint" in paragraph (4). The table of contents in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to replace "Annual adoption of concurrent resolution" with "Joint resolutions" for section 301 and to revise the item relating to section 303. The text discusses amendments to various legislative rules and acts, replacing "concurrent" with "joint" in different sections and clauses. Amendments are made to legislative rules and acts, changing "concurrent" to "joint" in different sections and clauses. The legislative rules and acts are amended by adding a new paragraph defining "direct spending" in accordance with the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The "Fiscal Discipline, Earmark Reform, and Accountability Act" is the short title for Title III. It includes reforms for the consideration of appropriations bills in the Senate. The "Fiscal Discipline, Earmark Reform, and Accountability Act" amends Rule XVI of the Standing Rules of the Senate to restrict the inclusion of new legislation or unauthorized appropriations in general appropriation bills. If a point of order is sustained, the offending provisions are removed from the bill or amendment. The "Fiscal Discipline, Earmark Reform, and Accountability Act" amends Senate rules to remove new legislation or unauthorized appropriations from general appropriation bills if a point of order is sustained. Amendments to bills are deemed adopted if they strike such provisions and adjust total appropriations accordingly. If a point of order is sustained against a Senate amendment, it is deemed out of order and cannot be considered. The Senate amendment is sustained by striking unauthorized appropriations and making necessary modifications to total amounts. If a point of order is sustained against a House amendment, an amendment is deemed adopted that removes new legislation or unauthorized appropriations and adjusts total amounts. The Senate amendment strikes unauthorized appropriations and adjusts total amounts. A point of order under subparagraph (a) may be waived by a three-fifths vote. The Presiding Officer's ruling on a point of order can be upheld unless three-fifths of Senators vote otherwise. A Senator can raise a point of order on multiple provisions in an appropriation bill, with the Presiding Officer able to strike down some or all of them if the point of order is sustained. Before ruling on a point of order, any Senator can move to waive it, which can be appealed after the ruling. Definitions for terms like 'new or general legislation' and 'unauthorized appropriation' are provided in this paragraph. The term 'unauthorized appropriation' refers to a 'congressionally directed spending item' that is not specifically authorized by law or exceeds the authorized amount. An unauthorized appropriation is not specifically authorized if it is restricted or directed to an identifiable person, program, project, entity, or jurisdiction by earmarking or other specification, unless clearly identified in a law or Treaty stipulation. The conference report on a general appropriation bill cannot include new or general legislation, unauthorized appropriations, new matter, or nongermane matter. If a point of order is sustained, the offending items will be struck from the report and necessary adjustments to total appropriations will be made. When all other points of order have been addressed, the Senate will consider whether to recede from its amendment to the House bill or its disagreement with the House amendment and concur with a further amendment. This further amendment will only include the portion of the conference report not struck and any modifications to total appropriations. If the Senate agrees to the amendment, the bill and Senate amendment will be sent back to the House. The Senate amendment will be returned to the House for concurrence. A point of order under subparagraph (a) may be waived by a three-fifths vote. An appeal from the Presiding Officer's ruling on a point of order requires a three-fifths vote to overturn. A Senator can raise a single point of order. A Senator can raise a single point of order on provisions in a conference report. The Presiding Officer may sustain the point of order on some or all provisions. A motion to waive the point of order can be made before the ruling. The ruling can be appealed with a three-fifths vote. The Senate allows Senators to appeal the Presiding Officer's ruling on a point of order regarding provisions in a conference report. Conference reports must be searchable online according to an amendment to the Standing Rules of the Senate. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to require recipients of Federal funds to report any payments made to lobbyists for lobbying activities related to the funding received.
